description: circa 1650, from Ancient Greek ἀσύμπτωτη (asúmptōtē), the feminine of Apollonius Pergaeus' (circa 200 BC) Ancient Greek adjective ἀσύμπτωτος (asúmptōtos, “not falling together”), from ἀ- (a-, “not”) +‎ συν- (sun-, “together”) +‎ πτωτός (ptōtós, “fallen”).

entries.meaning: (mathematical analysis) A straight line which a curve approaches arbitrarily closely as it goes to infinity. The limit of the curve; its tangent "at infinity".
(by extension, figuratively) Anything which comes near to but never meets something else.
examples: Language, in relation to thought, must ever be regarded as an asymptote.

verbs.description: asymptote (third-person singular simple present asymptotes, present participle asymptoting, simple past and past participle asymptoted)

entries.meaning: (mathematical analysis) To approach, but never quite touch, a straight line, as something goes to infinity.
examples: As you become more scientific, yes, the religiosity drops off, but it asymptotes.
